title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than merely restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the most significant effect of the printing press in the period 1450–1650.
The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the most significant effect of the printing press in the period 1450–1650.

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must relate the topic of the prompt to broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question. This point is not awarded for merely a phrase or a reference.
descriptions: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the effects of the printing press in the period 1450–1650.
The response describes a broader historical context relevant to the effects of the printing press in the period 1450–1650.

title: PART C1: EVIDENCE – PROVIDES EVIDENCE
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn one point, the response must identify specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.
descriptions: The response does not provide specific examples of evidence relevant to the effects of the printing press in the period 1450–1650.
The response provides specific examples of evidence relevant to effect of state centralization by European monarchs during the period 1450–1648

title: PART C2: EVIDENCE – USES EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT AN ARGUMENT
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must use specific historical evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.
descriptions: The response does not support an argument using specific examples of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.
The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using specific and relevant examples of evidence.

title: PART D1: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – USES HISTORICAL REASONING
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn the point, the response must demonstrate the use of historical reasoning to frame or structure an argument, although the reasoning might be uneven or imbalanced.
descriptions: The response does not use historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, continuity and change) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt, nor does it demonstrate a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt.
The response uses historical reasoning (e.g. comparison, causation, continuity and change) to frame or structure an argument that addresses the prompt.

title: PART D2: ANALYSIS AND REASONING – COMPLEXITY
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate a complex understanding.

This can be accomplished in a variety of ways, such as the following:

· Explaining the nuance of an issue by analyzing multiple variables

· Explaining both similarity and difference, or explaining both continuity and change, or explaining multiple causes, or explaining both causes and effects

· Explaining relevant and insightful connections within and across periods

· Confirming the validity of an argument by corroborating multiple perspectives across themes

· Qualifying or modifying an argument by considering diverse or alternative views or evidence

This understanding must be part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.
descriptions: The response does not demonstrate a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt.

The response demonstrates a complex understanding of the historical development that is the focus of the prompt, using evidence to corroborate, qualify, or modify an argument that addresses the question.
